content: I've just updated the statement to make it more neutral.

In the current state of the statement, how are we supposed to know whether the answer to the following input:
3
ABA
BAB
ABA
is 1 or 0?

Edit: The statement has since then been edited to add "The water does not leak diagonally."

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The description is clear. The problem is challenging and interesting. The test cases give good coverage, with my attempt at a solution failing several times at subsequent test cases.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: More challenging than it first seemed!

It misses some explanations to be doable in 15 minutes without too much extrapolation:
 - water level cannot be higher than the highest "wall"
 - a pool may be composed of several "zones" separated by walls. Each area may have different water levels.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I have tested the default code in all languages and it works.  I'd like to suggest that the default response be hard coded to the solution of the first test case, so when testing all the languages a nice "pass" is shown.  Great challenge.  It took me about 20 to 30 minutes, was brute force with no optimization required, so around the "Easy" range seems inline with the difficulty of other 'easy / medium' challenges.  I like it, so I am Accepting this contribution.  Thanks!

I gave this a shot for half an hour, but ultimately I have no idea what this puzzle is asking me to do. Find the volume based on the heights of the bottom of the pool I assume? I can see in the solution the water level is somehow dependent on the cells around it, but I don't get how that's in the description. 

I'm assuming you want to know how much water is in each zone of a pool if it is allowed to drain and there is water left in the pool afterwards. 

Based on the puzzle statement alone I would rate this as a hard puzzle as the puzzle description is the bottleneck. But ultimately I would abandon all hope of solving this based on not knowing what it's asking. 

Maybe some ascii art would help the idea. Here's a helpful diagram idea. 

http://chat.codingame.com/pastebin/8c1a9997-0da6-4975-920d-482f5f55e535

(I copy my comment from the CoC puzzle)

You don't state that water only flows in the 4 directions E/W/N/S (It is generaly the case for this type of puzzle, but I won't say it is so obvious).

Some clear testcase miss, to show that the pool can be compartimented with different water level.

For the difficulty : seem OK for me as an easy puzzle (certain persons even will say that is a medium puzzle)

Too difficult for a Coc.  Too easy for a puzzle?

https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/5965e6e4941a568cbb58e1301e72b58bc0c7
hard to be a genious. I understand.
I added a couple more N=10 testcases to make debug easier.  I don't see diagonal flow as a concern, a 3D structure of cubes wouldn't act like that.

Thanks for the feedback. Maybe looking at the jpeg at the top of the page helps?  It is just asking if you put together a bunch of blocks of the height indicated, how much water volume would they physically hold.

You guys are killing me, you guys plow through all these impossible graph theory puzzles like they are nothing, then they call this one too hard :P

--- solution rot13 ---
vzcbeg flf
vzcbeg zngu
vzcbeg ahzcl nf ac

a = vag(vachg())

c = ac.mrebf([a,a]) # cbby urvtug
sbe v va enatr(a):
    sbe w,p va rahzrengr(vachg()):
        c[v,w] = beq(p) - beq('N') + 1

j = ac.neenl(c) # jngre urvtug
j[1:a-1,1:a-1] = ac.barf([a-2,a-2])*26

p = Gehr # pbagvahr
juvyr p: #  sybj jngre hagvy abg sybjvat
    p = Snyfr
    j2 = ac.neenl(j) # qbhoyr ohssre bs j
    sbe v va enatr(1,a-1):
        sbe w va enatr(1,a-1):
            # zva bs znk bs fheebhaqvat jngre
            j2[v,w] = zva(ac.zva(ac.znkvzhz( c[v,w-1:w+2], j[v,w-1:w+2])) , ac.zva(ac.znkvzhz(c[v-1:v+2,w],j[v-1:v+2,w])))
            p = p be j2[v,w] != j[v,w]
    j = j2

# jngre urvtug
j = ac.znkvzhz(c,j)

cevag(vag(ac.fhz(j) - ac.fhz(c)))
It isn't a clash, you have more than 15 minutes.  I didn't understand the rest of the feedback.

I must admit, I really don't get why anyone would think it would leak diagonally.  I didn't even understand you were asking that question.  This is water we are talking about, not the movement of a chess piece or something.

Oh no! I never even associated the image at the top with actual puzzle. So many of them are just cover art that my brain filtered it out. 

Inside the IDE, only your user background image is shown. That's where I spend all my time trying. It's only really visible here in the contribute page.
